moves.6. b3 c5 7. dxc5 Bxc5 8. Bb2 Nc6 9. Nc3: Now both sides have cleared the minor pieces off the back rank and the real game begins.
The first major piece ventures out, combining attack and defense.
moves.15. cxd5 Nb4 16. dxe6 Bxe6: I lost a Pawn in the mix-up but with my active pieces my positional advantage is sufficient compensation.
moves.17. e3 Rad8: Seizing the only fully open file.
moves.18. Qc1 Nd3 19. Qb1 Nxb2: Getting rid of White's only active piece.
moves.20. Qxb2 Rd7 21. Rfd1 Rfd8: Doubling to keep control of the vital file.
moves.22. Rxd7 Rxd7 23. Ne1 Ne5: Planning to again use the Q file, this time for my remaining Knight.
moves.24. Nc2 Nd3: Seizing a powerful outpost with tempo.
moves.25. Qb1 Qd2: Looking to mount a direct attack against the King and force a mate or decisive material gain. Note that White is horribly cramped, with no piece beyond the second rank or Pawn beyond the third. The *attack* is the way to exploit an opponent's cramped position.
moves.26. Na3 Qxf2+: Forcing the King to the corner.
moves.27. Kh1 Nb2: Clearing the vital Q-file -- my invasion route for the entire attack -- for the Rook's entry.
moves.28. Be4 Rd1+: Winning Q and P for N and R, leaving me with a decisive material advantage in the coming end game.
moves.30. Rxd1 Qxe3: ...complete, and with the King in the corner, White's B is tied to the long diagonal to prevent a Bishop mate.
moves.31. Rd8+ Kf7: The value of "luft" -- if I hadn't made it earlier, the Rook check would have been mate.
moves.32. Bxh7 Bg4: White overlooks the mating threat, and I move my B into position.
